Prompt:
Example 1:
Cosmology (from the Greek kosmos, "world" and logia, "study of"), is the study of the origin, evolution, and eventual fate of the universe. Physical cosmology is the scholarly and scientific study of the origin, evolution, large-scale structures and dynamics, and ultimate fate of the universe, as well as the scientific laws that govern these realities.
The term cosmology was first used in English in 1656 in Thomas Blount's Glossographia, and in 1731 taken up in Latin by German philosopher Christian Wolff, in Cosmologia Generalis.
Religious or mythological cosmology is a body of beliefs based on mythological, religious, and esoteric literature and traditions of creation and eschatology.
Physical cosmology is studied by scientists, such as astronomers and physicists, as well as philosophers, such as metaphysicians, philosophers of physics, and philosophers of space and time. Because of this shared scope with philosophy, theories in physical cosmology may include both scientific and non-scientific propositions, and may depend upon assumptions that can not be tested.

Example 2:
It was believed by the principal men of Virginia that Talbot's sympathies were with the revolted colonies; but the influence of his mother, to whom he had been accustomed to defer, had hitherto proved sufficient to prevent him from openly declaring himself. His visit to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound him to his native country, and he found himself in a state of indecision as humiliating as it was painful. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and position and high personal qualities. It was hinted by one that the ancient barony of the Talbots would be revived by the king; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of having materially aided in acquiring that independence which should be the birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When to the last plea was added the personal preference of Katharine Wilton, the balance was overcome, and the hopes of the mother were doomed to disappointment.

The term nutrition was first used in the late 15th century in the sense of the natural process of growth and development, and in the 18th century in the sense of the science of dietetics. Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Graduate), limited to 200 words. 
Nutrition (from the Latin nutrire, "to nourish"), is the scientific study of the nutrients and substances that are needed by the human body to stay healthy. Nutritional science (or nutritional biology) is a branch of biochemistry, biology, and medicine that deals with the study of nutrients and other substances that are necessary for the health of living organisms. Because of the relationship between nutrition and health, nutritional science has become an increasingly important field of study in the fields of medicine, public health, and agriculture. A nutritionist is a person who has received special training in the study of nutrition and is qualified to advise people on healthy eating and diet. The main goals of nutritional science are to understand how nutrients and other substances affect human health and to develop healthy eating habits that promote optimal health. The study of nutrition also has implications for food production, food safety, and food policy. It has become an increasingly important field of study in the fields of medicine, public health, and agriculture.

Nutrition (from the Latin nutrire, "to nourish") is the scholarly and scientific study of the relationship between diet and health, which involves the investigation of the chemical composition and nutritional value of food and its effect on human health. The term nutrition was first used in English in 1593 in a Latin dictionary by Robert Cawdrey. Physical nutrition is the study of the intake, processing, and utilization of nutrients by the body, and their impact on overall health and well-being. 

Nutritional research can be categorized into two main areas: biochemical and biological. Biochemical nutrition examines the chemical composition and nutritional value of food and its impact on human health, while biological nutrition explores the biological processes that govern nutrient uptake and utilization. The study of nutrition has applications in various fields, including medicine, agriculture, and public health policy. A comprehensive understanding of nutrition is essential for the development of evidence-based dietary recommendations and the prevention of nutrition-related diseases. As a field, it encompasses biochemistry, physiology, psychology, and public health, among others. The term nutrition has been used in English since the 15th century, with the first scientific study of nutrition dating back to the late 19th century, when the discovery of vitamins revolutionized the field. Since then, the study of nutrition has been refined, with research now covering not only the biochemistry of nutrients, but also their impact on human health, disease, and overall well-being. It has also evolved to incorporate the social and cultural contexts of food consumption and nutrition, recognizing that dietary choices are shaped by a complex interplay of individual, societal, and environmental factors. His visit to England, and the delightful reception he had met with there, had weakened somewhat the ties which bound him to his native country, and he found himself in a state of indecision as humiliating as it was painful. Lord Dunmore and Colonel Wilton had each made great efforts to enlist his support, on account of his wealth and position and high personal qualities. It was hinted by one that the ancient barony of the Talbots would be revived by the king; and the gratitude of a free and grateful country, with the consciousness of having materially aided in acquiring that independence which should be the birthright of every Englishman, was eloquently portrayed by the other. When to the last plea was added the personal preference of Katharine Wilton, the balance was overcome, and the hopes of the mother were doomed to disappointment.

Nutrition (from the Latin nutrire, "to nourish") is the study of the biochemical and physiological processes that occur within an organism to sustain life and growth. It is the scholarly and scientific study of the substances and processes necessary to maintain health and performance. The term nutrition has been used in English since the 15th century, and in Latin since the 16th century, with various meanings, including the process of nourishing and the study of what we eat.

Physiological nutrition is the study of the processes that occur within the organism, such as digestion, absorption, and metabolism, to maintain health and performance. It is concerned with the chemical and physical processes that occur in the body, such as the breakdown and synthesis of nutrients, the transport of nutrients and oxygen, and the excretion of waste products.
